facts.text: Writ Petition No. 170 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

issues.text: whether Pakistan is a foreign power

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is whether Pakistan is a foreign power. On a direct interpretation of the meaning of the words the relations of India with foreign powers we have no doubt that Pakistan must be regarded as a foreign power, although that country may be a part of the Commonwealth as India is.

issues.text: whether the grounds of detention are vague and do not disclose sufficient particulars to enable the petitioner to make a representation

anchor.surface_text: Regarding ground No. 2 it was urged that it does not disclose a single suggestion about the subversive activities of the petitioner, nor does it disclose what portions of the despatches were false, incomplete, misleading or one-sided.

issues.text: whether there was violation of the principles of natural justice because the respondents case was heard by the Advisory Board prior to the case of the petitioner and in his absence and copies of further materials were not supplied

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged that in violation of the principles of natural justice the respondents case was heard by the Advisory Board prior to the case of the petitioner and in his absence and that copies of the further materials, which were placed before the Advisory Board by the respondent, were not supplied to the petitioner.

issues.text: whether ground No. 1 is outside the scope of the order of detention

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to objections made as to the grounds of detention regarding ground No. 1, it was urged that this ground was outside the scope of the order of detention. This ground mentions that the petitioner is engaged in carrying on propaganda against the Government of India and the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir

issues.text: whether none of the acts alleged disclose incitement to violence or subversion so as to be prejudicial to the security of India

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged on behalf of the petitioner that none of the extracts of the, despatches and the grounds of detention disclose any word or phrase suggesting incitement to violence or subversion of the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir or of the Government of India. Accordingly, there could be no question of any act of the petitioner being prejudicial to the security of India.

issues.text: whether non-disclosure of further facts is justified against public interest

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 22 (6) of the Constitution it is clearly stated that nothing in cl. (5) of that Article shall require the authority making an order of detention to disclose facts which such authority considers to be against public interest to be disclosed.

holdings.text: The extracts from the despatches annexed to the grounds of detention disclose sufficient particulars to enable the petitioner to make a representation to the Advisory Board and sufficient grounds for the action taken by the Central Government in detaining the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: We have examined the various extracts from the despatches sent by the petitioner annexed to the grounds of detention served upon him. They disclose sufficient particulars to

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court directly examined the extracts and found they provide enough detail based on content.

holdings.text: Pakistan must be regarded as a foreign power, although that country may be a part of the Commonwealth as India is.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is whether Pakistan is a foreign power. On a direct interpretation of the meaning of the words the relations of India with foreign powers we have

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning of 'foreign powers' in PD Act s.3 and foreign affairs; distinction from 'Foreign State' under Constitution Order which applies only to specific constitutional purposes; sovereign status of Pakistan.

holdings.text: Ground No.1 is not beyond the scope of the order of detention because bringing the Government of India and the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir into hatred and contempt does involve the security of India.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it cannot be said that this ground is beyond the scope of the order of detention because the bringing of the Government of India and the Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir into hatred and contempt does involve the security of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Propaganda bringing governments into hatred and contempt prejudicial to security of India under PD Act s.3.

holdings.text: None of these contentions has any substance because with the grounds of detention were annexed extracts from the despatches sent by the petitioner to the newspaper Dawn published in Pakistan. These extracts gave sufficient particulars to enable the petitioner to make a representation with respect to all matters stated in the grounds of detention.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, none of these contentions has any substance because with the grounds of detention were annexed extracts from the despatches sent by the petitioner to the newspaper

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annexed extracts to Dawn provide specifics on alleged falsity, misleading info etc., curing any vagueness.

holdings.text: There is nothing in s. 10 which offends against the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory procedure under ss.9-10 requires Board to consider govt materials first, then hear detenue if necessary; no right to hear before govt case.

Under Art. 22(6) of the Constitution...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public interest non-disclosure stated in grounds; authorized by Art.22(6).

holdings.text: The extracts of the despatches... show that they are not only prejudicial to the Government of India vis-a-vis Pakistan but they are prejudicial to the relations of India with foreign powers in general, the subject of the affairs of the State of Jammu and Kashmir not being a matter of interest solely to Pakistan but also of interest to other foreign powers.

anchor.surface_text: The extracts of the despatches, sent by the petitioner to the foreign newspaper, annexed to the grounds of detention show that they are not only prejudicial to the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Content of despatches on J&K affects international relations beyond Pakistan.
